descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: The gender division of labor is a key organizing principle in all known societies, but it takes a fascinating array of forms. In industrialized and post-industrial societies, women have taken up paid employment (while still doing the majority of caring and household labor) but men's take-up of traditionally feminine caring labor has been far more limited. Scholars debate about whether and how this will change, and whether political initiatives can influence these arrangements. In this course, we will investigate the ways in which work - paid and unpaid, in families and in places of employment - is organized by gender. We will examine family divisions of labor: how do men and women divide domestic work and care for children? What are the consequences for outcomes in paid employment and in terms of the distribution of time, respect, and power? We will learn about the development of the modern economy and occupational sex segregation, as well as how men and women are treated at work. Finally, we will consider the role of government policy in sustaining or changing these arrangements. By the end of the course, students should understand how gender influences the kinds of work we do and how it is rewarded, as well as how the economy is organized along gendered lines.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Open to sociology majors and minors & BIP minors during preregistration. This course is open to all undergraduates during regular registration beginning February 22, 2016.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
We will read four books, and a number of articles, which will be available online on Blackboard.


The following required books will be available for purchase at Norris (or you may order online), and will also be placed on reserve:


Andrea Doucet, Do Men Mother? (Toronto: University of Toronto Press, 2007)

Pierrette Hondagneu-Sotelo, Domestica: Immigrant Workers Cleaning and Caring in the Shadows of Affluence (Berkeley: University of California Press, 2001)

Rosabeth Moss Kanter, Men and Women of the Corporation (New York: Basic Books, 1993, second edition)

Kimberly Morgan, Working Mothers and the Welfare State: Religion and the Politics of Work-Family Policies in Western Europe and the United States (Stanford, CA: Stanford University Press, 2006) ISBN-13: 9780804754132
